content.raw: For convenience, we should consider letting user set damping or stiffness separately.  Requiring setting both coefficients through `SetStiffnessDamping` is less efficient when someone just wants to set one of the two parameters.
content.html: For convenience, we should consider letting user set damping or stiffness separately. Requiring setting both coefficients through SetStiffnessDamping is less efficient when someone just wants to set one of the two parameters.

content.raw: repeated call to `SetStiffnessDamping` causes console dump of `gzwarn` here because `stiffnessDampingInitialized` is already set to true even if parent and child are not static.  Need to fix this logic.
content.html: repeated call to SetStiffnessDamping causes console dump of gzwarn here because stiffnessDampingInitialized is already set to true even if parent and child are not static. Need to fix this logic.

content.raw: In the Advance Robotics department in Italian Institut of Technology we are developing Humanoid Robots with elastic joints and we would like to describe them with URDF and maybe also simulate them in GAZEBO. For this reason we are interested in this issues :)
content.html: In the Advance Robotics department in Italian Institut of Technology we are developing Humanoid Robots with elastic joints and we would like to describe them with URDF and maybe also simulate them in GAZEBO. For this reason we are interested in this issues :)

content.raw:
This mechanism adds spring damper forces to an existing joint.  So to model series elastic elements, I suppose one could construct an actuating joint and an elastic joint in series.  For example:
~~~
<model name="se_test_model">
  <link name="robot_base_body"/>
  <link name="actuated_piston"/>
  <link name="output_body"/>
  <joint name="motor_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>robot_base_body</parent>
    <child>actuated_piston</child>
  </joint>
  <joint name="elastic_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>actuated_piston</parent>
    <child>output_body</child>
    <axis>
      <stiffness>[series elastic element stiffness]</stiffness>
    </axis>
  </joint>
</model>
~~~
Where an actuating force(torque) can be applied on the `motor_joint` and the output forces are filtered through the `elastic_joint`.  Is that something you had in mind?
content.html:
This mechanism adds spring damper forces to an existing joint. So to model series elastic elements, I suppose one could construct an actuating joint and an elastic joint in series. For example:

<model name="se_test_model">
  <link name="robot_base_body"/>
  <link name="actuated_piston"/>
  <link name="output_body"/>
  <joint name="motor_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>robot_base_body</parent>
    <child>actuated_piston</child>
  </joint>
  <joint name="elastic_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>actuated_piston</parent>
    <child>output_body</child>
    <axis>
      <stiffness>[series elastic element stiffness]</stiffness>
    </axis>
  </joint>
</model>

Where an actuating force(torque) can be applied on the motor_joint and the output forces are filtered through the elastic_joint. Is that something you had in mind?

content.raw: Thank you very much!
content.html: Thank you very much!

content.raw:
I though removing initialization of the deprecated member error would fix the warnings, but I still get warnings:
~~~
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc: In constructor ‘gazebo::physics::Joint::Joint(gazebo::physics::BasePtr)’:
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc:46:17: warning: ‘gazebo::physics::Joint::dampingCoefficient’ is deprecated (declared at /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/Joint.hh:485) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
/home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc:46:17: warning: ‘gazebo::physics::Joint::useCFMDamping’ is deprecated (declared at /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/gazebo/physics/Joint.hh:523) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
~~~
I don't know of a way to deprecate individual member variables without generating compiler warnings.
